skills.name: Draw a cumulative frequency diagram from grouped data

explanations.A: Mass goes on the 洧논 axis, as this is the grouped variable we are investigating.
explanations.B: The grouped variable we are investigating goes on the x axis. What is this?
explanations.C: I think you have given the y axis. The grouped variable we are investigating goes on the x axis. What is this?
explanations.D: We do plot at the upper bound, but the upper bound of what?

explanations.A: I think you have given the x axis. What do we plot on the y axis for a cumulative frequency diagram?
explanations.B: We do use the frequency to work out what we plot on the y axis, but we do a running total. What is this called?
explanations.C: A cumulative frequency diagram always has cumulative frequency on the 洧녽 axis.
explanations.D: We do plot the point on the upper bound of the group, but this tells us the the x coordinate. What do we plot up the side of a cumulative frequency diagram?

explanations.A: I think you have given the x axis. What do we plot up the side of a frequency polygon?
explanations.B: A frequency polygon always has frequency on the 洧녽 axis.
explanations.C: This would be the y axis for a cumulative frequency graph, but we are drawing a frequency polygon.
explanations.D: We do plot the point on the midpoint of the group, but this tells us the the x coordinate. What do we plot up the side of a frequency polygon?

explanations.A: I think you have given me the x axis. What do we plot up the side of a histogram?
explanations.B: Not quite, on a histogram the frequency is the area of the bar. What do we plot on the side?
explanations.C: I think you are confusing histograms and cumulative frequency diagrams. What is up the side for a histogram?
explanations.D: A histogram always has frequency density on the 洧녽 axis.

explanations.A: A histogram always has frequency density on the 洧녽 axis.
explanations.B: A histogram is made up of bars, with the width of the bar being determined by the grouped variable. What is the height of the bar in a histogram?
